work.p: These notes may connect to the following line in the first poem of the 1855 Leaves of Grass, later titled "Song of Myself": "What is commonest and cheapest and nearest and easiest is Me" (1855, p. 21).

titleStmt.title: The most superb beauties
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

notesStmt.note: These notes, or possibly trial lines, expressing the idea that beauty is found in what is "cheapest" and "commonest," may be connected to the following line in the first poem of the 1855 Leaves of Grass, ultimately titled "Song of Myself": "What is commonest and cheapest and nearest and easiest is Me." The date is most likely before or early in 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Suggestions for Poems

revisionDesc.change: checked; revised respository information in header
converted from P4 to P5, checked

body.ab: The most superb beauties and are in the cheapest
The most bdivinest blessings are in the commonest bestowed every where, and the most superbest beauties are the cheapest, the world over.—
